t: Job 30
But*p now they that are younger than I have me in derision, whose fathers I would have disdained to have set with the dogs of my flock.
Yea,*p whereto might the strength of their hands profit me, in whom old age was perished?
For*p want and famine they were solitary; fleeing into the wilderness in former time desolate and waste.
Who*p cut up mallows by the bushes, and juniper roots for their meat.
They*p were driven forth from among men, (they cried after them as after a thief;)
To*p dwell in the cliffs of the valleys, in caves of the earth, and in the rocks.
Among*p the bushes they brayed; under the nettles they were gathered together.
They*p were children of fools, yea, children of base men: they were viler than the earth.
And*p now am I their song, yea, I am their byword.
They*p abhor me, they flee far from me, and spare not to spit in my face.
Because*p he hath loosed my cord, and afflicted me, they have also let loose the bridle before me.
Upon*p my right hand rise the youth; they push away my feet, and they raise up against me the ways of their destruction.
They*p mar my path, they set forward my calamity, they have no helper.
They*p came upon me as a wide breaking in of waters: in the desolation they rolled themselves upon me.
Terrors*p are turned upon me: they pursue my soul as the wind: and my welfare passeth away as a cloud.
And*p now my soul is poured out upon me; the days of affliction have taken hold upon me.
My*p bones are pierced in me in the night season: and my sinews take no rest.
By*p the great force of my disease is my garment changed: it bindeth me about as the collar of my coat.
He*p hath cast me into the mire, and I am become like dust and ashes.
I*p cry unto thee, and thou dost not hear me: I stand up, and thou regardest me not.
Thou*p art become cruel to me: with thy strong hand thou opposest thyself against me.
Thou*p liftest me up to the wind; thou causest me to ride upon it, and dissolvest my substance.
For*p I know that thou wilt bring me to death, and to the house appointed for all living.
Howbeit*p he will not stretch out his hand to the grave, though they cry in his destruction.
Did*p not I weep for him that was in trouble? was not my soul grieved for the poor?
When*p I looked for good, then evil came unto me: and when I waited for light, there came darkness.
My*p bowels boiled, and rested not: the days of affliction prevented me.
I*p went mourning without the sun: I stood up, and I cried in the congregation.
I*p am a brother to dragons, and a companion to owls.
My*p skin is black upon me, and my bones are burned with heat.
My*p harp also is turned to mourning, and my organ into the voice of them that weep.
